Detailed Description

This abstract class represents a flag, or, in Views 2 terminology, "a handler".

This is the base class for all flag implementations. Notable derived classes are flag_node and flag_comment.

Member Function Documentation

flag_flag::applies_to_content_id ( $  content_id  ) 

Returns TRUE if the flag applies to the content with the given ID.

This is a convenience method that simply loads the object and calls applies_to_content_object(). If you already have the object, don't call this function: call applies_to_content_object() directly.

flag_flag::applies_to_content_object ( $  content  ) 

Returns TRUE if the flag applies to the given content. Derived classes must implement this.

Reimplemented in flag_node, flag_comment, and flag_user.

flag_flag::construct (  ) 

Default constructor. Loads the default options.

flag_flag::default_options (  ) 

Declares the options this flag supports, and their default values.

Derived classes should want to override this.

Reimplemented in flag_node, flag_comment, and flag_user.

flag_flag::delete (  ) 

Deletes a flag from the database.

flag_flag::disable (  ) 

Disable a flag provided by a module.

flag_flag::enable (  ) 

Enable a flag provided by a module.

flag_flag::factory_by_array ( $  config  ) 

Create a complete flag (except an FID) from an array definition.

flag_flag::factory_by_content_type ( $  content_type  )  [static]

Another factory method. Returns a new, "empty" flag; e.g., one suitable for the "Add new flag" page.

flag_flag::factory_by_row ( $  row  )  [static]

Creates a flag from a database row. Returns it.

This is static method.

The reason this isn't a non-static instance method --like Views's init()-- is because the class to instantiate changes according to the 'content_type' database column. This design pattern is known as the "Single Table Inheritance".

flag_flag::fetch_content ( $  content_id,
$  object_to_remember = NULL 
)

Fetches, possibly from some cache, a content object this flag works with.

flag_flag::flag ( $  action,
$  content_id,
$  account = NULL,
$  skip_permission_check = FALSE 
)

Flags, on unflags, an item.

Parameters:
$action Either 'flag' or 'unflag'.
$content_id The ID of the item to flag or unflag.
$account The user on whose behalf to flag. Leave empty for the current user.
$skip_permission_check Flag the item even if the $account user don't have permission to do so.
Returns:
FALSE if some error occured (e.g., user has no permission, flag isn't applicable to the item, etc.), TRUE otherwise.

Reimplemented in flag_node.

flag_flag::form_input ( $  form_values  ) 

Update the flag with settings entered in a form.

flag_flag::get_content_id ( $  content  ) 

Given a content object, returns its ID. Derived classes must implement this.

Reimplemented in flag_node, flag_comment, and flag_user.

flag_flag::get_count ( $  content_id  ) 

Returns the number of times an item is flagged.

Thanks to using a cache, inquiring several different flags about the same item results in only one SQL query.

flag_flag::get_flag_action ( $  content_id  ) 

Returns a 'flag action' object. It exists only for the sake of its informative tokens. Currently, it's utilized only for the 'mail' action.

Derived classes should populate the 'content_title' and 'content_url' slots.

Reimplemented in flag_node, flag_comment, and flag_user.

flag_flag::get_label ( $  label,
$  content_id = NULL 
)

Processes a flag label for display. This means language translation and token replacements.

You should always call this function and not get at the label directly. E.g., do `print $flag->get_label('title')` instead of `print $flag->title`.

Parameters:
$label The label to get, e.g. 'title', 'flag_short', 'unflag_short', etc.
$content_id The ID in whose context to interpret tokens. If not given, only global tokens will be substituted.
Returns:
The processed label.

flag_flag::get_labels_token_types (  ) 

Returns the token types this flag understands in labels. These are used for narrowing down the token list shown in the help box to only the relevant ones.

Derived classes should override this.

Reimplemented in flag_node, flag_comment, and flag_user.

flag_flag::get_serialized_options (  ) 

Options are stored serialized in the database.

flag_flag::get_title ( $  content_id = NULL,
$  reset = FALSE 
)

A convenience method for getting the flag title.

`$flag->get_title()` is shorthand for `$flag->get_label('title')`.

flag_flag::get_user_count ( $  uid  ) 

Returns the number of items a user has flagged.

For global flags, pass '0' as the user ID.

flag_flag::insert (  ) 

Saves a new flag to the database. Better use save().

flag_flag::is_flagged ( $  content_id,
$  uid = NULL 
)

Returns TRUE if a certain user has flagged this content.

Thanks to using a cache, inquiring several different flags about the same item results in only one SQL query.

Parameters:
$uid Optional. The user ID whose flags we're checking. If none given, the current user will be used.

Reimplemented in flag_node.

flag_flag::options_form ( &$  form  ) 

Provides a form for setting options.

Derived classes should want to override this.

Reimplemented in flag_node, flag_comment, flag_user, and flag_broken.

flag_flag::remember_content ( $  content_id,
$  object 
)

Stores some object in fetch_content()'s cache, so subsequenet calls to fetch_content() return it.

This is needed because otherwise fetch_object() loads the object from the database (by calling _load_content()), whereas sometimes we want to fetch an object that hasn't yet been saved to the database. See flag_nodeapi().

flag_flag::replace_tokens ( $  label,
$  contexts,
$  content_id 
)

Replaces tokens in a label. Only the 'global' token context is regognized by default, so derived classes should override this method to add all token contexts they understand.

Reimplemented in flag_node, flag_comment, and flag_user.

flag_flag::save (  ) 

End of "addtogroup views". Saves a flag to the database. It is a wrapper around update() and insert().

flag_flag::theme ( $  action,
$  content_id,
$  after_flagging = FALSE 
)

Renders a flag/unflag link. This is a wrapper around theme('flag') that, in Drupal 6, easily channels the call to the right template file.

For parameters docmentation, see theme_flag().

flag_flag::theme_suggestions (  ) 

Provides an array of possible themes to try for a given flag.

flag_flag::update (  ) 

Saves an existing flag to the database. Better use save().

flag_flag::user_access ( $  account = NULL  ) 

Returns TRUE if user has access to use this flag.

Parameters:
$account Optional. The user object. If none given, the current user will be used.
Returns:
Boolean TRUE if the user is allowed to flag/unflag. FALSE otherwise.

flag_flag::uses_hook_link ( $  teaser  ) 

Returns TRUE if the flag is configured to show the flag-link using hook_link. Derived classes are likely to implement this.

Reimplemented in flag_node, flag_comment, and flag_user.

flag_flag::validate (  ) 

Validates a flag settings
